column4: Hi all, does ubuntu have a special way of managing memory? http://rafb.net/p/XxSINL44.html <-- 2Gb total, 77MB free, 5MB buffers, 83MB cache, 330MB total RSS and 640MB swap !
330MB resident used by progs, but only 165MB free (counting buffers and cache), who is using the other 1.5GB ?
I think the word "used" is miss-leading in the current kernel (not just ubuntu) think of it free as "controlled by the kernel" and free as "not allocated by the kernel"
sorry, think of "used" as "controlled by the kernel" and "free" as "not allocated by the kernel"
I still don't understand why this system is swapping so much nor who is using that much ram
I can't even malloc 200Mb without swapping
the system will swap out "unused" processes to disk
ooh, really, you can't malloc 200mb, thats not right
I'm paying more attention to what you've got running now
I'll try closing all apps and see what happen, but I doubt I'll see more than 400MB free or cached
just adding up what you've got running (not residial foot print, but in use memory)
ooh, I didn't think you'd get that much back
I don't know which process was doing that, maybe gvfsd
or another, I killed some of my user process
actually I think cache+buffers+free+total rss should be >= total memory-kernel memory
